so one important concept that we need to understand like it's relevant
for for the other slides is fault domains i'm sure you've heard of the expression
what happens in vegas stays in vegas um so that's pretty much what we're trying to do so the point of having
these two separate regions is obviously the closer we are to the customer
the lower the latency is right so the web pages are going to render a lot quicker etc
but we also try to keep them fully isolated so the idea is
a request that goes to the blue region stays there like all of the services that
operate in the blue region they only interact with other services in that region
and the same for the green one like there's no cross region calls
and the point of all this is to create these fault domains so in the event of a failure they don't cascade they don't
propagate to to the other region so we have full isolation
or that's what we're trying to to achieve and and this is how it looks like um
so we have our customers at the top usually you have a cdn like you think
fastly akamai etc that when the user tries to access our
website they direct it to the closer region and then once the request enters say the
blue one it only interacts with the services there these blue things this is just they're

like deployments or pods there um and we have full set
like the full stack so data stores etc so again there's no need to have

domains um
yes so let's say that there's an incident and let's say that it's a really big one like for some reason

doesn't matter like everything on on the green region is
is unavailable um
what most companies do and what xpd also traditionally does is basically they
root or they divert all of the traffic at the edge uh and i think this image captures that
so we're shifting like we're closing the green region everyone now needs to go to the the other uh the backup one
the other the only one that's still healthy and you can imagine that there's there's a ton
there's there are tons of issues with the with this approach this is like the nuclear option and you can even see in
the image there's a lot of contention so we're shifting a lot of traffic
that's going to result in higher latencies it's going to result in issues
so if you think that if the data center the entire data center is unavailable it's not going to be just your company
who's trying to move it's going to be everyone like all of the companies here like farfetch'd and flutters and
whatever they're all trying to rush to the to the other available region um and
what this means is does amazon or does google or microsoft do they have enough capacity sometimes
they don't so if you wait too long you'll try to shift traffic and then oh there's no more ec2s available for you
so this is it's a nice option to have but it's also a nuclear option if that makes sense
and then we also have like what if there's a tiny little incident it's just a tiny little service
that's the sun available again the analogy with roads like if there's a pothole we're not gonna close
the highway right it doesn't make sense you could but then it comes with all of these

so this is what we try to do instead of shifting all of the traffic
all of the users to the healthy region we just divert the
traffic the traffic of the services that we're interacting with the one that's now unhealthy
um it does mean that now the vegas rules they don't apply now

means we modified the route 53 entries and it's very very basic um
and very simple to implement but it does have a lot of drawbacks so dns is cached everywhere right so
even if you click the button there's a long delay until traffic actually
um starts moving because the dns entries they need to expire they need to be resolved again and then if you think
with the http 3 with like grpcs etc you have a long of a lot of long-lived
connections or even persistent connections so well i mean there wasn't a surprise to
us but what we saw was that you click the button and then nothing happens or it takes a really

have this option but just as a catch-all
